Aux:TextAnnotations.Aux:document_text: In the summer of 1942, the day which became known as "black Shabbat", all Jewish men aged from 18 to 45 were commanded to present themselves at the square to be put to forced labour. On the same day, 6,000 or 7,000 of them were gathered in the square, guarded by armed German soldiers. The gathered crowd was publicly tortured and humiliated before being registered. The Nazis requested a ₯2.5 billion ransom to release the Jews from forced labour, which the community paid to them. Ultimately this incident was only the start. Adolf Hitler had planned to incorporate Thessaloniki directly into the Third Reich as a reprisal for its involvement in the First World War (Salonica Front), and the Nuremberg Laws were gradually implemented by the Nazi authorities. Under the orders of SS officers Dieter Wisliceny and Alois Brunner, between 15 March and August 7, 1943 Thessaloniki's 56,000 Jews were deported, by use of 19 holocaust trains, to Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen concentration camps, where at least 43,000 – 49,000 of them were killed; Only 2,000 Jews returned after the war, of 4% of the pre-war numbers, and less than 1,000 remain today.
